overview: When you need planning permission, where to apply, what counts as permitted development and how to appeal a planning permission decision
title: Planning permission (England and Wales)

table.body:
You will probably need planning permission if you want to:

+ build something new
+ make a major change to your building - eg building an extension
+ change the use of your building

To find out if your project will need planning permission, contact your [local planning authority (LPA).](http://www.planningportal.gov.uk/wps/portal/genpub_LocalInformation?docRef=LocalInformation&scope=202&langid=0 "Find your local planning authority"){:rel="external"}

##Applying for planning permission
You can [apply for planning permission](http://www.planningportal.gov.uk/planning/applications/planningapplications "Apply for planning permission"){:rel="external"} online.

If your project needs planning permission and you do the work without getting it, you can be served an ‘enforcement notice’ ordering you to undo all the changes you have made. 

%It's illegal to ignore an enforcement notice, but you can [appeal](/planning-permission-england-wales/appeals "Appealling a planning permission decision") against it.%

*[LPA]: Local planning authority
table.title: When you need it
When you don't need it

table.body:
Your local planning authority (LPA) will decide whether to grant planning permission for your project based on its development plan. It will not take into account whether local people want it.

To decide whether a planning application fits with its development plan, an LPA will look at:

+ the number, size, layout, siting and external appearance of buildings
+ the infrastructure available - eg roads and water supply
+ any landscaping needs
+ what you want to use the development for
+ how your development would affect the surrounding area - eg if it would create lots more traffic

In most cases, planning applications are decided within 8 weeks. In England, for unusually large or complex applications the time limit is 13 weeks. If the decision takes longer, you can [appeal](planning-permission-england-wales/appeals "Appeal a planning permission decision").

*[LPA]: Local planning authority
table.title: After you apply

table.body:
If your application is refused, try to come to an agreement with the local planning authority (LPA) by adjusting your plans.

If you can’t reach an agreement, you can [appeal.](http://www.planningportal.gov.uk/planning/appeals "Appeal a planning permission decision"){:rel="external"}

You must appeal within a [time limit.](http://www.planningportal.gov.uk/planning/appeals/guidance/timelimits "Find out about time limits for planning permission appeals on the Planning Portal"){:rel="external"}

Appeals can take several months to be decided. 

##What you can appeal against

You can only appeal against a decision if the LPA:

+ refuses your application
+ grants permission but with conditions you object to
+ refuses to change or remove a condition of planning permission that has been granted with conditions
+ refuses to approve something reserved under an 'outline permission' – planning permission for a general idea, not of a specific plan
+ refuses to approve something that you were told to build by your LPA as part of a previous planning permission (ie the previous planning permission was granted 'with conditions' and the current development was one of the conditions)
+ does not make a decision on the application within the [deadline](/planning-permission-england-wales/after-you-apply "Planning permission in England and Wales (After you apply)") and doesn’t get your written consent to change the deadline
+ serves you with an [enforcement notice](/planning-permission-england-wales/when-you-need-it "Planning permission in England and Wales (When you need it)") because it thinks you have broken planning permission and you don't agree

The Planning Portal has [guidance on the appeals process.](http://www.planningportal.gov.uk/planning/appeals/planningappeals "Planning permission appeals - guidance"){:rel="external"}


*[LPA]: Local planning authority
